results.title: Click go the shears
results.creator_credit: Jerome Levy, Keith Gow and Link Films
results.brief_description: A highly stylised humorous treatment of the famous Australian ballad, using a minimum of animation. Sung by Cedric McLaughlin and the Link Singers.

results.title: Telephones: using and abusing
results.creator_credit: Jennie Blackwood, E Brereton and Post Office Film Unit
results.brief_description: A dramatised account promoting speedy and efficient use of the telephone. Guides us in the correct methods of dialling, answering and speaking on the telephone. With animation explains the complex sequence of operations within an automatic exchange when a call is made.

results.title: Smokes and Lollies
results.creator_credit: Gillian Armstrong, Penny Chapman, 1:1 Films and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: First film in a longitudinal study of three Adelaide girls, aged thirteen and fourteen. They talk about their attitudes to sex and boys, pregnancy, abortion, marriage, school, parenthood and their careers. Their hopes and ambitions pose special questions for adults and young people alike. Edited by David Pulbrook; sound by Rod Pascoe and photographed by Tom Cowan.

results.title: The Passionate industry: 1920-1930
results.creator_credit: Joan Long, Frank Bagnall and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “History of Australian Cinema Series”.
Traces the history of the Australian film industry in the decade 1920-1930. Includes material from fifty newsreels, sixteen feature films and still photographs drawn from our seventy collections. The program looks at the 1927 Royal Commission of Enquiry and Film Bill of 1927, as well as footage of the Regent, capitol and Old State Theatre of Melbourne.

results.title: Cyberthon VI: VAT
results.brief_description:
After the success of Spectrum, the Cyberthon artists were invited by Telstra to create a submission for an exhibition called The Edge, to be displayed at the Telstra Corporate Center on Exhibition Street. This demo was presented to Telstra at an annual meeting held at Dallas Brooks Hall.

The demo shows a CGI artists impression of the proposed ‘The Edge exhibition’ space as well as a simulation of the media submission process via the interactive Cyberthon VAT (V=Video, A=Audio, T=Text) porthole created using Deluxe Paint, with presentation edited in Scala on an Amiga 2000.

Animation loops that appear in simulated submission section were created by Ian Haig, Cyber Dada (Troy Innocent and Dale Nason), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton & Attillio Gangemi), Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Julian Wong, Mish Fingers (Misha Hollenbach), Derek Shiel, Martine Corompt, and Force Fed (Stuart McCormick). Video camera footage was shot by Dale Nason from the back of a Chris Wrights moving van. 35mm still photographs were taken by Tao Wiess. Audio track was mixed by DJ Visitor (Andrew Till).

This work is part of the Cyberthon Archive, generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Impression of Oakleigh Technical School. . a caring place
results.brief_description: An overview of Oakleigh Technical School as seen throught the eyes of Scott, one of the students. The school is show as having a vibrant school council with an innovative, stimulating program.

results.title: Planning for Melbourne's future
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Thompson, Cine Service and Melbourne and Metropolitan Board of Works
results.brief_description: In 1949 the Melbourne Metropolitan Board of Works was asked to formulate a plan that would estimate the future needs of Melbourne. From information gathered through surveys, inspecting every street and alley to determine its use, this was made possible. “Planning for Melbourne’s Future” is photographed and directed by Geoffrey Thompson and is an examination of this plan. It is a rare and honest account of the deficiencies and lack of planning made to prepare Melbourne for an increase in future population growth.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Geoffrey Thompson, Cine Service and Melbourne and Metropolitan Board of Works

results.title: Woolloomooloo
results.brief_description: A social and historical documentary on the redevelopment of one of Sydney’s oldest harbourside areas, from the initial plans of 1969 to the completion of the Housing Commission’s renovation project in late 1977. Details the roles of local, State and Federal governments, the State Planning Authority, The National Trust, the developers, the Builders’ Labourers Federation led by Jack Mundey, and the residents groups.

results.title: Derek Jarman's Blue
results.creator_credit: Derek Jarman, James MacKay, Takashi Asai and Basilisk Communications, Uplink
results.brief_description: Derek Jarman’s last film, made as he was dying from an AIDS related illness, is a devastating exploration of death and dying. Delivered in Jarman’s own voice-over, with assistance from Nigel Terry, Tilda Swinton and John Quentin, the film is a testimony to courage; it is also a farewell to love, and to life. By turns sad and exhilarating, the shimmering blue of the screen becomes a canvas across which the audience interacts with the essayist filmmaker. Jarman was one of the English-language world’s most daring, transgressive and experimental film artists and it is fitting that his last film continues his maverick’s love for exploration and the avant-garde. Right to the end, his wit and intelligence were undiminished. NOTE: VISUALS CONSIST OF BLUE SCREEN

results.title: A Man and his dog
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board and Supreme Sound Studios
results.brief_description: An account of the training of Kelpie dogs in the handling of sheep on an Australian sheep station. Explains the possible origin of the breed; shows the special training a dog receives from the time he is a small pup until he can muster and control a mob of a thousand or more sheep; shows the confidence of the dog and the bond of friendship which springs up between the animals and their masters.
